Description: Piece of curved worked mammal bone; part of the side of a cylindrical object? One side finished, following the curve, other sides broken off. Smooth outer surface with parts of three incised circles with central dots.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The design of dotted circles can be found on many types of objects in bone, such as handles (handle found in Cyprus: BM 1974,1101.14), plaques (plaques from the Temple of Artemis Orthia BM 1923,0212.611 -614) or even amuletic pendants (amulets from the Levant, normally dated to the 9th-8th century BC: Herrmann et al, 174; many pendants from Casviri cemetery in Kamiros, dated to the Orientalising Period, such as BM 1864,1007.618-620 and BM 1864,1007.664). A Greek, Cypriot or Levant origin is possible for such artefact, though an Egyptian one cannot be ruled out either. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (WB.12) (Phase 3)
